date.headline: Jerry's Guide to the World Wide Web
date.text: Jerry Yang and David Filo create "Jerry's Guide to the World Wide Web" while studying at Stanford University.

date.headline: Yahoo!
date.text: Jerry's Guide to the World Wide Web" is renamed "Yahoo!.

date.headline: Launch of the Yahoo! commercial website
date.text: Launch of the Yahoo! commercial website that includes advertisements and news feeds from Reuters. Tim Koogle is also named CEO of Yahoo!

date.headline: Yahoo! has Initial public offering
date.text: Yahoo! has Initial public offering, closing at US$33.00—up 270 percent from the IPO price—after peaking at US$43.00 for the day.

date.headline: Yahoo! acquires Four11
date.text: Yahoo! acquires Four11 for about US$94 million in stock.

date.headline: Four11's Rocketmail is incorporated into Yahoo! Mail.
date.text: Together with the ymail.com domain name, Four11's Rocketmail is incorporated into Yahoo! Mail.

date.headline: Yahoo! acquires Viaweb
date.text: Yahoo! acquires Viaweb, co-founded by Paul Graham, for US$49 million and transforms it into Yahoo! Store.

date.headline: Yahoo! acquires Yoyodyne Entertainment, Inc.
date.text: Yahoo! acquires direct marketing company Yoyodyne Entertainment, Inc.

date.headline: Yahoo! acquires Geocities
date.text: Yahoo! acquires Geocities for US$4.58 billion in stock.

date.headline: Yahoo! acquires Broadcast.com
date.text: Yahoo! acquires Broadcast.com for US$5.7 billion in shares.

date.headline: Yahoo stocks close at an all-time high of $475.00
date.text: Yahoo stocks close at an all-time high of $475.00 (pre-split price) a share. The day before, it hit an intra-day high of $500.13 (pre-split price).

date.headline: Yahoo Japan stocks on roll
date.text: At the height of the Dot-com tech bubble, shares in Yahoo Japan became the first stocks in Japanese history to trade at over ¥100,000,000, reaching a price of 101.4 million yen ($962,140 at that time).

date.headline: DDoS
date.text: Yahoo.com was brought to a halt for a few hours as it was the victim of a distributed denial of service attack (DDoS).[13][14] On the next day, its shares rose by about $16, or 4.5 percent, as the failure was blamed on hackers rather than on an internal glitch, as was the case with an eBay incident earlier that year.

date.headline: LICRA v. Yahoo!
date.text: In LICRA v. Yahoo!, a French judge ordered Yahoo to ban Nazi-related sites from its search engine, and to stop to act as an intermediary on bids for objects with racist overtones. Yahoo denied the French court's jurisdiction over a United States based company, and the tribunal's requests were finally abandoned in 2003. Yahoo eventually quit voluntarily trading on Nazi and Ku Klux Klan bibelots.

date.headline: Yahoo acquires eGroups
date.text: Yahoo CEO Tim Koogle announces he will step down and remain only a company board member.

date.headline: Yahoo acquires eGroups
date.text: Yahoo stocks close at an all-time low of $8.11. The day before, it hit an intra-day low of $8.02 (both figures are pre-split prices).

date.headline: Yahoo acquires eGroups
date.text: Hacker Adrian Lamo is convicted of compromising security at Yahoo!

date.headline: Yahoo acquires Sold.com
date.text: Yahoo! acquires Australian online auction site Sold.com from Fairfax Media and the latter gains AU$18.3 million.

date.headline: Yahoo bids for HotJobs
date.text: Yahoo bids $436 million for the job search engine HotJobs, defeating rival TMP Worldwide (Monster.com).

date.headline: Yahoo acquires HotJobs
date.text: Yahoo! completes its acquisition of HotJobs.

date.headline: SBC Communications and Yahoo!
date.text: SBC Communications and Yahoo! launch national co-branded dial service.

date.headline: Yahoo acquires Inktomi
date.text: Yahoo! starts acquisition of web search engine company Inktomi.

date.headline: BT Openworld announces an alliance with Yahoo!
